results.title: Freedom in the genes
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, David Sington, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Is behaviour inherited and destined since birth? This episode from the ‘Cracking the code’ series explores this question with the aid of the world’s largest gathering of twins, English sheepdogs, trained flies plus other animal assistants.

results.title: Body invaders
results.creator_credit: Paula S. Apsell, Bonnie Waltch, Christine Z Wiser, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Viruses and bacteria are able to change their genes rapidly, consequently beating and confusing the natural defenses within the bloodstream. If human knowledge can adapt to the task, theoretically AIDS could become a disease of the past.

results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Cracking the code”.
Geneticists can now offer a cure for some of the thousands of inherited diseases. This program explores the difficult personal, moral and ethical issues arising from this situation.

results.title: The Devils
results.creator_credit: Ken Russell, Robert H Solo and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: This erotic adaptation of Aldous Huxley’s “The Devils of Loudon” is based on a 17th Century incident of diabolical possession which affected a religious community in France. For Russell the foundations of religious hysteria is in the repressed sexuality, and the feudal heirarchy, of Catholic monastic life. Oliver Reed plays Father Grandier who refuses to collborate with the agents of Louis XIII who are attempting to challenge the power of the traditional clerical nobility. When Grandier is accused of sorcery by the Mother Superior of the Convent in Loudon (Vanessa Redgrave) a show-trial is commenced in which the Convent is exorcised of its “demons”. Russell, whose richly hallucinatory Catholic imagination has always been under-rated by Anglo-saxon critics, is able to give expression to both the pleasure and danger involved in sexuality. This fascinating film, anchored by the sharp spiritual insight of Huxley’s original novel, is one of the director’s best films.

results.title: Accidents of creation
results.creator_credit: Andrew Liebman, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Cracking the code”.
DNA, a simple chemical, defines the difference between every living animal and plant on earth. Differences arise from mutations; small changes in DNA working as the engine of evolution.

results.title: Birth, sex and death
results.creator_credit: Tim Haines, Paula S. Apsell, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Cracking the code”.
The cycle of human life is controlled by genes. Could genes also programme our time of death, or do they just prefer the offspring who carry on?

results.title: The Devil and Daniel mouse
results.creator_credit: Clive A Smith, Michael Hirsh, Patrick Loubert, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Nelvana
results.brief_description: Using traditional cell animation, the timeless story of the person who sells his soul to the devil in return for present success is told. Jan and Dan are a not-too-successful folk singing duo, when Jan signs a contract with the devil to become a famous rock singer. When the devil comes to collect Jan, Dan demands a trial. Photographed by Lenora Hume; script by Ken Sobol; edited by Bob Ablack; music by John Sebastian.

results.title: Learning
results.creator_credit: David Espar, Tuggelin Yourgrau and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Discovering psychology”.
For every animal the name of the game is survival. In order to achieve this all animals have inbuilt reflexes or ready made reactions to threats and fixed action patterns such as migration. In addition animals have, to a lesser or greater degree, a capacity to learn from experience. In this program Philip Zimbardo looks at different theories of learning, from Pavlov’s classical conditioning, Thorndike’s instrumental conditioning to B.F. Skinner’s operant conditioning. Includes archival film of classical experiments.

results.title: The Devil's toy
results.creator_credit: Claude Jutra, Marcel Martin and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The skateboard gave the youngsters, who mastered its technique, a thrilling sensation of speed unexcelled by any other pavement sport. Filmed in 1966 on Montreal streets before the elongated rollerskate was banned, this film captures the exuberance of boys and girls having the time of their lives in free-wheeling downhill locomotion. Music by Pierre Brault. Sung by Genevieve Bujold.
